author: poojaranjan
content:
Yes,  the ECH is celebrating with distributing London upgrade NFTs to as much as 100 contributors. Along with people involved with documenting notes, coordination process, the list contains every co-author of all 5 proposals, 5 for each client team, editors and many other who contributed in one way or the other. 

Our team has already started distributing NFTs with the public wallet available and reaching individuals.  If you know someone who is missed, please reach me, <@!641438053059264512> ,  <@!601063305070772244> on Discord.  Thanks!

author: tkstanczak
content: some miners are not filling blocks

author: timbeiko
content: <@!489256758989029405> what do you mean? That the block gas used is very variable, or that miners are leaving potentially valid transactions in the mempool?

author: tkstanczak
content: second probably but we will need more data

author: chfast
content: The basefee step feels too big (hard to ignore as a user). Any particular reason for such value?

author: timbeiko
content: <@!425274498732916736> we discussed this on ACD this AM, and the short answer is "not really". We probably want a value where it quickly becomes prohibitive to spam the network (e.g. we can't have a 1% increase), but it may be worth making it smaller by, say, half? It would be great to have people analyse this in more depth, and client teams said on ACD if we found a better parameter that was a "one line change", we could change it alongside the difficulty bomb delay in December

author: timbeiko
content: Yes, I think this also needs much more digging into. A very crude first metric would be to get data on the minimum, non-0, priority fee accepted by various miners

author: sky.cactus
content: Why do you think the second?

author: sky.cactus
content: And do you think this is any different from normal (pre London) empty blocks that we saw pre-London?

author: pietjepuk
content: On that note, maybe something that depends on more history/historical blocks? No idea how hard that would be to implement though (with short reorgs and all)

author: sky.cactus
content:
https://etherscan.io/tx/0x368eeba20ac349b5d245a53d568eb5d0285dc60dd8f236a00c472e837d9cd600
Attempt to create a contract starting with 0xfe.

author: sky.cactus
content: I am curious why it was decided to burn all gas rather than just revert with gas spent?

author: axic3354
content: Because it is implemented the same way invalid instruction / bad jumpdest / `INVALID` are.  Those were never changed to not consume all gas, only `REVERT` does that.

author: axic3354
content: We actually measured (not connected to this) how much we could "save" in a block with not consuming all gas in those cases, and it is not too much at this point as everyone uses `revert`, so only super broken cases end up with that.

author: sky.cactus
content: Super broken cases and my test-in-production.  üò¢

author: axic3354
content: Your donation is much appreciated üôè

author: sky.cactus
content: Who do I send my receipts to for a refund?

author: axic3354
content: To the masternode?

author: axic3354
content: Isn't this actually just a contract creation transaction with `0xef` as **initcode**?

author: sky.cactus
content: Gah, it is.  üò¢

author: sky.cactus
content: Unfortunately I already deleted the code I wrote to submit that transaction, and for reasons entirely unrelated to the `0xef` byte I'm now angry at software and refuse to write it again.

author: sky.cactus
content: Well, at least I'm helping to contribute to the burn.  üò¨
